p: Influenza A viruses infects a broad range of mammalian species. Interspecies transmission of AIVs, such as human H5N1 infections [50], [51], and the recent swine-origin H1N1 infections [52], [53], [54] have shed light on molecular changes in influenza A viruses that are involved with their adaptation to new species [55]. One recent study suggests that a HA with truncated glycans can recognize Î±2,3 sias with increased affinity and decreased specificity [56], and single amino acid changes within the HA can lead to complete loss of binding to sias residues and subsequent replication within the lungs [57]. Understanding these features is critical for disease intervention, as these steps are central in emergence of pandemic viruses.
